definition.text: When you contribute to Superalgos, you must produce a claim for your contribution, and you must harness the support of people working close to you, who will vouch or vote for your claims.

paragraphs.text: Content

Governance is decentralized. There is no central authority controlling who contributes what or what rewards contributors get. Instead, the project delegates in the Community the capacity to establish the value of contributions and to determine who contributed what.

As such, governance is a social system. When you get involved with Superalgos, you interact with the Community and find ways to contribute. While doing so, you relate to or associate with community members that have similar interests or are focused on the same areas of the project you may be working in. It is these people that will vouch for your claims!
There are three different types of claims you may place:
Asset Contribution Claim
Feature Contribution Claim
Position Contribution Claim
There are also three different folder types of nodes that act as organizational devices from which you may spawn the above claim nodes:
Asset Claims Folder
Feature Claims Folder
Position Claims Folder
These three types of claims match the three types of definition hierarchies used to describe the project:
Assets
Features
Positions

To place a claim, use the appropriate type of contribution claim node to reference the matching type of definition. For example, use an Asset Contribution Claim node to reference an Asset node within an Assets hierarchy. When you do that, you are effectively placing a claim on that asset.
This claim means that you declare that you have worked on that asset, either creating or improving it, and that you expect to be rewarded accordingly.
How a claim is resolved depends on three interelated concepts:
The Claim Power you drive into the node that places the claim.
The Claim Votes your claim gets from other users, and the Voting Power they drive into those votes.
The Token Rewards available within the definition node you are claiming.
To learn all the details about claims resolution, read the How Claims are Resolved page in the Governance Flow topic of The Governance Project book.
